Travellers to Bermuda must follow the requirements set-out in the Quarantine (COVID-19) (No.3) Order 2020.   Both visitors and residents must apply for a Bermuda COVID-19 Travel Authorisation 1 to 3 days before departure and cannot travel to Bermuda without an approved Travel Authorisation. Submission of a Travel Authorisation within 24 hours of your travel date will not be approved.  To obtain approval for a Travel Authorisation, visitors must provide proof of valid negative COVID-19 PCR test taken no more than 5 days* before arrival. (*For example, a pre-arrival COVID-19 PCR test taken on 4th December, will be valid for arrival in Bermuda until 9th December).   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210307104313/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-travellers

Bermuda’s National COVID-19 vaccination strategy has as its primary priority for the COVID-19 vaccination programme the prevention of COVID-19 mortality and the protection of health care workers, essential workers and social care staff and systems.  Secondary priorities include vaccination of those at increased risk of hospitalisation, at increased risk of exposure, and to maintain resilience in public services.  Link:https://web.archive.org/web/20210307105209/https://www.gov.bm/covid-19-vaccine-allocation-strategy

In the 4 February 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, there was a report on the province of Ontario’s decision to return elementary and secondary students in the regions of Windsor-Essex (bordering Detroit), Hamilton, Halton and Durham (suburban Toronto) to in-class learning at school on 8 February from online classes at home. However, schools in Toronto and surrounding suburban regions Peel and York continue to conduct classes online until 16 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210204192310/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-most-ontario-schools-will-return-to-in-class-learning-on-monday/

Effective 11 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador “Chief Medical Officer of Health has issued a modified special measures order for the St. John’s metro area: Schools and post-secondary educational institutions are closed.” As noted on 4 February 2021 schools in Canada’s largest city Toronto and surrounding suburban regions Peel and York continue to conduct classes online until 16 February 2021. Universities and colleges in Ontario’s urban areas are also holding online classes. In the rest of Canada, elementary and secondary schools are open. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210210221150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0210n09/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210204192310/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-most-ontario-schools-will-return-to-in-class-learning-on-monday/

On 19 February 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. Schools in Canada’s largest city Toronto and surrounding suburban regions Peel and York were scheduled to reopen (weather permitting) for in-school classes on 16 February. However, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador at alert level 5, “Schools and post-secondary educational institutions are closed.” See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210210221150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0210n09/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219144150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/education/files/Education-Online-Learning-english.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217021924/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-snow-disrupts-return-to-in-person-learning-in-three-ontario-covid-19/

On 26 February 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador at alert level 5, “the Chief Medical Officer of Health and the Provincial Government, advised that all schools would be moving to Scenario 3 - online instruction. This will continue until at least Friday, February 26, as part of province-wide efforts to reduce the risk of spreading COVID-19.” See Newfoundland and Labrador English School District website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210220172254/https://www.nlesd.ca/families/covid19-2021.jsp

On 8 march 2021, elementary and secondary schools are open in most of Canada. However, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), the Avalon Peninsula (St. John’s capital region) remains at alert level 5: “up to and including Friday, March 12 ...Online Instruction”. In the province of Ontario: “Schools in the City of Thunder Bay, and surrounding municipalities, will be closed for in-person learning starting Monday, March 1, 2021 for a period of at least 2 weeks.” See NL English School District and Thunder Bay District Health Unit websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301194915/https://www.nlesd.ca/families/covid19-2021.jsp  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307112853/https://www.tbdhu.com/currentlevel

On 5 February 2021, the Province of Ontario (the most populous in Canada) continues to enforce closures and restrictions on non-essential businesses as do Quebec, New Brunswick and other jurisdictions. Some provinces have started a gradual reopening. See GOVERNment of Ontario website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201191314/https://www.ontario.ca/page/enhancing-public-health-and-workplace-safety-measures-provincewide-shutdown  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205140421/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-number-of-covid-19-cases-in-first-nations-communities-has-dropped-to/

Effective 11 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador “Chief Medical Officer of Health has issued a modified special measures order for the St. John’s metro area: Gym and fitness facilities, yoga studios, swimming pools, tennis and squash facilities, arenas, dance studios and performance spaces are closed. Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service, but can offer online/telephone sales with delivery or curbside pick-up options. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed. Restaurants are closed for in-person dining. Take-out, delivery and drive-thru options are permitted. Bars, lounges, bingo halls and cinemas are closed.” Other provinces have started or announced intentions to begin a gradual reopening. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210210221150/https://www.gov.nl.ca/releases/2021/health/0210n09/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211161415/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/editorials/article-will-doug-fords-reopening-plan-be-a-booster-shot-for-the-pandemic/

On 19 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador remains at alert level 5: “Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service … Restaurants are closed for in-person dining ...Businesses that hold a license under the Liquor Control Act whose primary purpose is the consumption of beer, wine, or spirits are closed. Cinemas are closed. Bingo halls are closed. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed.” Non-essential businesses remain closed in Canada’s largest city Toronto, two suburban Toronto regions and a northern Ontario region pending a decision by the Ontario government. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217214201/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219151305/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reports-1038-new-covid-19-cases-44-additional-deaths/

On 25 February 2021, the province of Newfoundland and Labrador remains at alert level 5: “Gym and fitness facilities are closed, including yoga studios, swimming pools, tennis and squash facilities, and arenas. Dance studios and performance spaces are closed...Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service … Restaurants are closed for in-person dining ...Businesses that hold a license under the Liquor Control Act whose primary purpose is the consumption of beer, wine, or spirits are closed. Cinemas are closed. Bingo halls are closed. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed.” Non-essential businesses remain closed in Canada’s largest city Toronto, a suburban Toronto region and a northern Ontario region “until March 8”. See Government of Newfoundland and Labrador and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219150436/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225163539/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reports-975-new-covid-19-cases-and-12-additional-deaths/

On 8 march 2021, in the province of Newfoundland and Labrador (NL), the Avalon Peninsula (St. John’s capital region) remains at alert level 5: “Gym and fitness facilities are closed, including yoga studios, swimming pools, tennis and squash facilities, and arenas. Dance studios and performance spaces are closed...Retail stores that do not provide services essential to life, health or personal safety of individuals and animals are closed to in-person service … Restaurants are closed for in-person dining ...Businesses that hold a license under the Liquor Control Act whose primary purpose is the consumption of beer, wine, or spirits are closed. Cinemas are closed. Bingo halls are closed. Personal service establishments, including spas, esthetic services, hair salons, body piercing, tattooing and tanning salons, are closed.” However, on this date 8 March previously closed non-essential businesses are opening with restrictions in Canada’s largest city Toronto and a suburban Toronto region. See Government of NL and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210306142205/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/alert-system/alert-level-5/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307120054/https://toronto.ctvnews.ca/this-is-what-can-reopen-when-toronto-and-peel-region-go-into-the-grey-zone-on-monday-1.5334937

On 5 February 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force: “A Province-wide declaration of emergency is in effect. Stay home except for essential reasons. … Indoor organized events … are not permitted...Meeting and event spaces are closed...Concert venues, theatres and cinemas are not permitted to open for any purpose.” Other provinces (but not all) have imposed similar rules. See City of Toronto website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210129185219/https://www.toronto.ca/home/covid-19/covid-19-reopening-recovery-rebuild/covid-19-reopening-guidelines-for-businesses-organizations/covid-19-guidance-indoor-outdoor-events/

***Updated to add note supporting 2T rather than 2G coding; pulled from subnational coding    As of February 8, 2021, the Nova Scotia government further eased restrictions. Businesses are now allowed to host events and activities. The government is also now allowing for spectators at events, large facilities to host events of up 100 people, and up to 100 people or 50% of the venue's capacity with social distancing for events and activities hosted by a recognized business or organization. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210208123445/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20210205008

On 11 February 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force in the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city): “Stay home except for essential reasons. … Indoor organized events … are not permitted...Meeting and event spaces are closed...Concert venues, theatres and cinemas are not permitted to open for any purpose.” Other provinces have imposed similar rules, but not all -- e.g., Nova Scotia now allowing public events with restrictions. (See C3 note for 08Feb2021.) On 24 February 2021, the City of Toronto (Canada’s largest city) announced “extending the cancellation of in-person City-led and City-permitted major outdoor events to July 1, including Canada Day parades, festivals and fireworks. Today’s announcement includes festivals and other large, in-person gatherings held at outdoor sites managed by the City or other public locations, such as roads, parks and civic squares.” Other jurisdictions have imposed similar rules, but not all -- e.g., Nova Scotia allowing public events with rules. See City of Toronto websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225045219/https://www.toronto.ca/news/city-of-toronto-extends-cancellation-of-in-person-major-events-to-july-1/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210218051016/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/docs/Events-theatres-and-venues-COVID-19-prevention-guidelines.pdf

On 25 February 2021, the Province of Ontario’s Regulation 82/20 continues in force in the City of Toronto ( Canada’s largest city “Toronto remains subject to the Lockdown Regulation–Shutdown Zone and Stay-at-Home Order... Restrict gatherings to people you live with only. Having family or friends who are not members of your household in your home for a social visit is prohibited under provincial orders... social gatherings are not permitted, except with members of the same household. On 11 February 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew in southern Quebec and 9:30 pm to 5 am in less populated northern Quebec where covid cases per capita are lower. Quebec continues to be the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211181641/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-reopens-non-essential-stores-salons-and-museums-as-covid-19-2/

On 19 February 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew in southern Quebec and 9:30 pm to 5 am in less populated northern Quebec where covid cases per capita are lower. Quebec continues to be the only province or territory in Canada with a curfew. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219164023/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-reports-669-new-covid-19-cases-and-20-additional-deaths/

On 24 february 2021, in the territory of Nunavut, a 10 pm to 6 am curfew took effect in Arviat (population 2,800). The entire province of Quebec remains under curfew with times varying by region. See Toronto Star website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302213853/https://www.thestar.com/politics/2021/03/02/mayor-in-nunavut-hopes-curfew-order-bylaw-patrol-will-bring-drop-in-covid-19-cases.html

On 25 February 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew in Monteal and other southern Quebec regions and 9:30 pm to 5 am in northern and western Quebec regions where covid cases per capita are lower. See government of Quebec website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222151959/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/progressive-regional-alert-and-intervention-system/level-4-maximum-alert-red/

On 8 march 2021, the Province of Quebec continues to enforce a 8 p.m. to 5 a.m. curfew in Montreal (largest city) and surrounding regions, while moving more regions to the 9:30 pm to 5 am curfew already in force in northern and western Quebec regions. Quebec continues to be the only province in Canada with a curfew. In the territory of Nunavut, the 10 pm to 6 am curfew in force in Arviat (population 2,800) is due to be lifted 8 March. See CTV news and Toronto Star websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210307173506/https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/all-of-quebec-to-become-orange-zone-on-march-8-except-for-montreal-and-surrounding-areas-1.5332367  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302213853/https://www.thestar.com/politics/2021/03/02/mayor-in-nunavut-hopes-curfew-order-bylaw-patrol-will-bring-drop-in-covid-19-cases.html

On 5 February 2021, the province of Manitoba continued to enforce ’s requirement: “Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205145805/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 11 February 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “The self-isolation order continue to require that anyone entering Manitoba, regardless of whether it was from another country or another province must self-isolate for 14 days” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211182733/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 19 February 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “As per the public health order, 14 days of self-isolation is required for people returning or coming to Manitoba from all jurisdictions. Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which now apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219164644/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html

On 25 February 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “As per the public health order, 14 days of self-isolation is required for people returning or coming to Manitoba from all jurisdictions. Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which also apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic region travel no longer applies. See Province of Manitoba and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219164644/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224144057/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/prince-edward-island/pei-covid-travel-bubble-1.5924514

On 8 march 2021, the province of Manitoba is still stating: “As per the public health order, 14 days of self-isolation is required for people returning or coming to Manitoba from all jurisdictions. Individuals who travelled internationally or inter-provincially must go into mandatory self-isolation (quarantine) for 14 days from the date of arrival to Manitoba.” The 4 Atlantic provinces impose similar rules, which also apply to inter-provincial travel within the Atlantic region. The Atlantic bubble exception for intra-Atlantic travel now applies only between the provinces of Nova Scotia (NS) and Prince Edward Island. See Provinces of Manitoba and NS websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308141157/https://www.gov.mb.ca/covid19/restartmb/prs/orders/index.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210227195137/https://novascotia.ca/coronavirus/restriction-updates/

On 5 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “If you're a foreign national (not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident of Canada) … There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment...Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice to limit the spread of COVID-19...Travellers entering Canada must, during your 14-day period while in quarantine or isolation, stay in a hotel while waiting a negative result of their molecular test.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205151123/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

On 11 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “If you're a foreign national (not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident of Canada) … There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment...Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice to limit the spread of COVID-19...Travellers entering Canada must, during your 14-day period while in quarantine or isolation, stay in a hotel while waiting a negative result of their molecular test.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211183357/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

On 19 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “If you're a foreign national (not a Canadian citizen or a permanent resident of Canada) … There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment. If a traveller's entry is permitted, they'll be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days... Canadian citizens and permanent residents are advised to avoid all non-essential travel outside of Canada until further notice to limit the spread of COVID-19...There are no exemptions from mandatory quarantine for travellers entering Canada.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219165800/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

On 25 February 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise: “There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment. If a traveller's entry is permitted, they'll be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days...There are no exemptions from mandatory quarantine for travellers entering Canada.” See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224071107/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/latest-travel-health-advice.html

On 8 march 2021, the Government of Canada continues to advise that “the COVID-19 pandemic restricts travel to Canada ... There are currently border restrictions for discretionary (optional) travel to Canada at the Canada-U.S. border and from any country other than the U.S. Discretionary travel includes, but is not limited to, tourism, recreation and entertainment. If a traveller's entry is permitted, they'll be subject to mandatory quarantine for 14 days...There are no exemptions from mandatory quarantine for travellers entering Canada.” See government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210304121640/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308142827/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions

As of 5 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to pay the Canada Recovery Benefit to self-employed Canadians who have lost income. As of 5 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are similar. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205194713/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 19 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are similar. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219181517/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 25 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are similar. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219181517/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

As of 3 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend: “Contact your local health authority for advice about testing if you think you may have COVID-19 (and/or) have been in contact with someone who has COVID-19.” Provincial, territorial and local public health approaches are broadly similar. Testing has recently been extended to asymptomatic individuals in “outbreak” regions in Atlantic Canada, but asymptomatic testing remains the exception, not the rule. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308144053/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

In a 10 February Globe and Mail newspaper article, the City of Hamilton’s Medical Officer of Health laments that the province of Ontario’s “reopening plans are emerging just as her staff have recovered their ability to keep up with the task of tracing all the contacts of confirmed cases”. Since other regions have higher daily case per capita counts than Hamilton, it is probable that contact tracing delays are continuing in other parts of Canada. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210211133106/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-medical-officers-in-some-covid-19-hot-spots-push-back-against-ontarios/

As of 19 February 2021, there is not enough evidence to say that contact tracing is back to comprehensive in all regions of Canada. In a Globe and Mail newspaper opinion column, Dr. Brooks Fallis expressed dissatisfaction by urging provincial and territorial governments: “Focus contact tracing efforts on high-risk areas that continue to drive transmission and properly invest in local public health units so we can rapidly trace every contact.” See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217153210/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-canada-is-sleepwalking-into-a-third-wave-and-it-could-be-the-worst-one/

On 25 February 2021, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada warned: “Any easing of public health measures must be done slowly with enhanced testing, screening, and genomic analysis to detect variants of concern. In particular, there must be sufficient contact tracing capacity”. This concern suggests that contact tracing may not be comprehensive in all regions of Canada. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225201518/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2021/02/statement-from-the-chief-public-health-officer-of-canada-on-february-25-2021.html

In the 8 march 2021 print edition of the Globe and Mail newspaper, the president of the Ontario Hospital Association was quoted by Canadian Press: “When the pandemic’s over, we have to have a very good look at how we can strengthen our capability with other preventative measures such as testing and tracing.” This concern provides further evidence that contact tracing may not be comprehensively keeping up with case volumes in all regions of Canada. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308144931/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-toronto-has-had-some-of-the-longest-covid-19-business-closures-in/

As of 5 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask or face covering when you're in public and you might come into close contact with others; you're in shared indoor spaces with people from outside your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. With British Columbia imposing more extensive mask requirements in schools, Canada is getting closer to 3G. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205201144/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205200054/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-bc-makes-masks-in-middle-and-high-school-classrooms-mandatory/

As of 11 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask or face covering when you're in public and you might come into close contact with others; you're in shared indoor spaces with people from outside your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces, but not all, have stringent mask requirements. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210212012948/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html

As of 19 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., British Columbia exempts elementary school students. See Government of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219184203/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213205449/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/british-columbia/covid-19-bc-school-guidelines-enhanced-health-and-safety-measures-announced-1.5899483

As of 25 February 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., British Columbia exempts elementary school students at their desks. See Government of Canada and Globe newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224134806/http://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210225202506/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/british-columbia/article-covid-19-variant-in-schools-means-its-time-for-all-students-in-bc-to/

As of 8 march 2021, the government of Canada continues to recommend that Canadians “wear a non-medical mask when you’re in a shared space (indoors or outdoors) with people from outside of your immediate household; advised by your local public health authority”. Most provinces and territories require all adults and children to wear masks in public spaces, but there are some exceptions -- e.g., some provinces exempt elementary school students at their desks (in some regions). See Government of Canada and CTV news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308145352/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/prevention-risks/about-non-medical-masks-face-coverings.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308150044/https://bc.ctvnews.ca/teachers-ask-elementary-school-kids-in-other-provinces-have-to-wear-masks-so-why-not-in-b-c-1.5325795

As of 5 February 1:30 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 89.1% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 883,648 Canadians [2.3% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 150,807 Canadians [almost 0.4%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has resulted in a slower pace of vaccinations.However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210131010943/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205162839/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/gov

***Updated to add link providing further support for 3 groups being vaccinated   A, B, C  As of 11 February 1:30 pm EST, according to an unofficial vaccine tracker website, “doses of COVID-19 vaccines (including both Moderna and Pfizer-BioNTech) have been delivered to the provinces for administration. As of today, 90.5% of doses delivered to the provinces have been administered...As of today, more than 940,304 Canadians [almost 2.5% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 235,924 Canadians [0.6%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19, having received both required doses.” A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations.However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue with first doses to three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See covid19tracker.ca and government of Canada websites, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20210211185843/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities0.html https://web.archive.org/web/20210211190042/https://covid19tracker.ca/vaccinationtracker.html

As of 19 February 11:12AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,007,878 Canadians [2.65% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine. 372,911 Canadians [almost 1%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past 4 weeks. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes).See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210217180702/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210219184842/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509

As of 26 February 10:21AM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1,231,835 Canadians [3.2% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna or Pfizer. 497,318 Canadians [1.3%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. A slowdown in vaccine delivery to Canada has led to a slower pace of vaccinations over the past month. However, vaccine supply appears sufficient for the time being to continue vaccinations for three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). In some provinces/territories, vaccinations are starting or are about to start for elderly persons living in the community outside of care homes. On 26 Feb. 2021, Health Canada authorized the AstraZeneca vaccine (including the version from the Serum Institute of India) for use in Canada for those aged 18 and up. See CTV news, Globe newspaper, and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224122201/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226155631/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-health-canada-approves-astrazenecas-covid-19-vaccine-for-people-over/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226160443/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-with-a-mass-expansion-of-the-covid-19-vaccine-program-just-weeks-away/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210226160132/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/02/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities2.html

A,B,C: On 1 March 2021, the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) “recommended against using the AstraZenec-Oxford vaccine in people aged 65 and older, although Health Canada has authorized it to be used in adults of all ages”. Most, and perhaps all, Canadian provinces and territories accepted NACI’s recommendation and updated their vaccination plans. See CBC news website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308155125/https://www.cbc.ca/news/health/astra-zeneca-vaccine-naci-age-1.5932347

A,B,C: On 3 March 2021, the National Advisory Committee on Immunization (NACI) “recommends that in the context of limited COVID-19 vaccine supply, jurisdictions should maximize the number of individuals benefiting from the first dose of vaccine by extending the interval for the second dose of vaccine to four months”. Most, and perhaps all, Canadian provinces and territories accepted NACI’s recommendation and updated their vaccination plans to include the four-month interval. See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308154413/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/rapid-response-extended-dose-intervals-covid-19-vaccines-early-rollout-population-protection.html

A,B,C: On 5 March 2021, “Health Canada authorized the COVID-19 vaccine manufactured by Janssen Inc. [owned by Johnson & Johnson]…. for use in people over 18 years of age”. “Health Canada has now approved four distinct COVID-19 vaccines, with the others being from Pfizer-BioNTech, Moderna and Oxford-AstraZeneca.” The Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are being administered to Canadians. Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines may not have been administered yet. The first shipment to Canada arrived 3rd March. See CBC news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305211028/https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/naci-interval-advice-change-four-months-1.5934563  https://web.archive.org/web/20210305203353/https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2021/03/health-canada-authorizes-janssen-covid-19-vaccine.html

As of 8 March 2021 1:30PM EST, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 1864745 Canadians [4.9% of the national population] have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna or Pfizer. 567,954 Canadians [almost 1.5%] are fully vaccinated against COVID-19 having received two doses. Vaccinations are targeted on three priority groups: A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). In some provinces/territories, vaccinations have started for elderly persons living in the community outside of care homes. According to Canada’s Minister of Indigenous Services, “more than 127,000 COVID-19 vaccine doses have been administered in more than 480 First Nations, Inuit and Territorial communities... approximately 40% of the indigenous population in First Nations, Inuit and Territorial communities having received at least one dose.”  See CTV news and government of Canada websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308184423/https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/coronavirus/coronavirus-vaccine-tracker-how-many-people-in-canada-have-received-shots-1.5247509  https://web.archive.org/web/20210308160146/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/03/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities.html

As of Feb. 3, five states, and the District of Columbia, have state-ordered partial closures in effect. Puerto Rico is still on full closure, however Puerto Rico is not state in the USA.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210209023204/https://www.edweek.org/leadership/map-where-are-schools-closed/2020/07

As of March 5th, there are no states with full closures at any level. However, some states have orders mandating specific guidelines for reopening (i.e. in New Mexico all schools were allowed to begin hybrid teaching on Feb. 8, but must follow certain safety protocols including testing) and some states require schools in counties that exceed thresholds to close (e.g. Delaware and Hawaii).     Most states have no statewide order in effect. A few states have mandated that all schools offer an in-person option and will only close individual schools in exceptional circumstances under local authority (e.g. Arkansas, Iowa).     Puerto Rico--not a state but rather a US territory--allowed students to return to school with restrictions on March 1. It was the only remaining place in the US to have a mandated school closures at all levels.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308014835/https://www.edweek.org/leadership/map-where-are-schools-closed/2020/07    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308015106/https://www.puertoricoheadlinenews.com/first-phase-of-school-reopening-begins/

States such as Michigan and Vermont have bars and Nightclubs closed.  State by State Restriction - http://web.archive.org/web/20210209023547/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html    Michigan - http://web.archive.org/web/20210209023251/https://www.michigan.gov/coronavirus/

As of March 4th, there are few restrictions in place, but some states still order some sectors to close. For example, bars are still closed statewide in Vermont. Many states have curfews for certain types of businesses, especially restaurants.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020436/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html
No Policy Change.  State by state restrictions - http://web.archive.org/web/20210209023547/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

As of March 4th, many states still limit both public and private gatherings. Most states do not prohibit all such gatherings, but rather limit the allowed capacity. However, at least one state (Colorado) prohibits all indoor public gatherings in areas that exceed certain thresholds.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020436/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

No Policy Change. States such as Virginia, Ohio, Arkansas, Massachusetts etc still restrict gatherings to 10people or less.    State by state Restrictions -http://web.archive.org/web/20210209023547/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

Many states still limit gatherings to 10 or fewer people, at least in counties/areas with substantial spread (e.g. Colorado, New Mexico).     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020436/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

Public transit is operating in most areas with restrictions and service reductions. Masks are required on all public transit and in all transportation hubs per the CDC.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210306220344/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/face-masks-public-transportation.html

Curfew is in effect in states such as North Carolina, Ohio, Virginia etc.  State by state Restrictions -http://web.archive.org/web/20210209023547/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

As of March 4th, no generally applicable curfews are in force. In at least one state (South Dakota) the elderly and other vulnerable individuals are encouraged to stay at home.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308020436/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

See latest internal travel restrictions, some states still require quarantine and/or negative covid-19 test result - http://web.archive.org/web/20210209024835/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/10/travel/state-travel-restrictions.html

As of March 5, some restrictions on inter-state travel remain. In Alaska, for example, domestic passengers who test positive within 72 hours of their flight's departure are barred from entry to the state.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308022747/https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/10/travel/state-travel-restrictions.html

There is still a ban in the following countries China, Iran, Most European Countries, UK, Ireland, Brazil and South Africa. All travelers (including US citizens and transit passenger) must present a negative COVID-19 viral or antigen test result issued 72 hours prior to departure or have an evidence of having contracted and recovered from COVID-19 prior to boarding the plane.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210209025559/https://www.kayak.com/travel-restrictions

As of March 4th, restriction of entry of certain foreign nationals and foreign nationals who have travelled through designated high-risk countries are barred entry to the United States.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/https://www.kayak.com/travel-restrictions#united-states
Current Employment benefits are valid until March   http://web.archive.org/web/20210209031824/https://blog.dol.gov/2021/01/11/unemployment-benefits-answering-common-questions
http://web.archive.org/web/20210209032535/https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/05/biden-moving-forward-with-food-assistance-ahead-of-stimulus.html
Coordinated public campaign by CDC and the States.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210209034317/https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-nCoV/index.html
http://web.archive.org/web/20210209035453/https://www.hhs.gov/coronavirus/community-based-testing-sites/index.html
No Policy change.  State by State Restrictions - http://web.archive.org/web/20210202004853/https://www.aarp.org/politics-society/government-elections/info-2020/coronavirus-state-restrictions.html

A  Doses are for Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine and Moderna Vaccine  According to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention vaccine tracker, on 7th February, about  31,579,100 people have received at least one dose of a Covid-19 vaccine, including about 9,147,185 people who have been fully vaccinated. Total doses administered is 41,210,937.  CDC - http://web.archive.org/web/20210209031955/https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#vaccinations   State by State Vaccination campaign - http://web.archive.org/web/20210207202801/https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2021/01/28/960901166/how-is-the-covid-19-vaccination-campaign-going-in-your-state

A, C:    On February 27th, Johnson & Johnson/Janssen Pharmaceuticals was granted an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA) for its single-dose covid-19 vaccine. The first dose of this vaccine was administered in Columbus, Ohio on March 3rd.     In most of the country elderly groups are eligible for vaccination.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308042252/https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/02/us/first-johnson--johnson-covid-vaccine-shot-columbus-ohio/index.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210227212257/https://www.aarp.org/health/conditions-treatments/info-2020/coronavirus-vaccine-distribution.html    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210304154620/https://www.fda.gov/news-events/press-announcements/fda-issues-emergency-use-authorization-third-covid-19-vaccine

A,C:    J&J, Moderna, and Pfizer vaccines are being administered.     As of March 7th, 90,351,750 doses of vaccine had been administered, with 30,686,881 individuals having received both doses.     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308040257/https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/
